defs.docs: Concurrent work-stealing deques.

attributes.value: / These data structures are most commonly used in work-stealing schedulers. The typical setup
/ involves a number of threads, each having its own FIFO or LIFO queue (*worker*). There is also
/ one global FIFO queue (*injector*) and a list of references to *worker* queues that are able to
/ We spawn a new task onto the scheduler by pushing it into the *injector* queue. Each worker
/ thread waits in a loop until it finds the next task to run and then runs it. To find a task, it
/ first looks into its local *worker* queue, and then into the *injector* and *stealers*.
/ [`Injector`] is a FIFO queue, where tasks are pushed and stolen from opposite ends. It is
/ shared among threads and is usually the entry point for new tasks.
/ * [`new_fifo()`] - Creates a FIFO queue, in which tasks are pushed and popped from opposite
/ * [`new_lifo()`] - Creates a LIFO queue, in which tasks are pushed and popped from the same
/ Each [`Worker`] is owned by a single thread and supports only push and pop operations.
/ Method [`stealer()`] creates a [`Stealer`] that may be shared among threads and can only steal
/ tasks from its [`Worker`]. Tasks are stolen from the end opposite to where they get pushed.
/ Steal operations come in three flavors:
/ 2. [`steal_batch()`] - Steals a batch of tasks and moves them into another worker.
/ 3. [`steal_batch_and_pop()`] - Steals a batch of tasks, moves them into another queue, and pops
/ In contrast to push and pop operations, stealing can spuriously fail with [`Steal::Retry`], in
/ which case the steal operation needs to be retried.
/ Suppose a thread in a work-stealing scheduler is idle and looking for the next task to run. To
/ find an available task, it might do the following:
/ 1. Try popping one task from the local worker queue.
/ 2. Try stealing a batch of tasks from the global injector queue.
/ 3. Try stealing one task from another thread using the stealer list.
/ An implementation of this work-stealing strategy:
/     // Pop a task from the local queue, if not empty.
/         // Otherwise, we need to look for a task elsewhere.
/             // Try stealing a batch of tasks from the global queue.
/                 // Or try stealing a task from one of the other threads.
/         // Loop while no task was stolen and any steal operation needs to be retried.
/         // Extract the stolen task, if there is one.

defs.name: Worker
defs.docs: A worker queue.

attributes.value: / This is a FIFO or LIFO queue that is owned by a single thread, but other threads may steal
/ tasks from it. Task schedulers typically create a single worker queue per thread.

defs.name: new_fifo
defs.docs: Creates a FIFO worker queue.

attributes.value: / Tasks are pushed and popped from opposite ends.

defs.name: new_lifo
defs.docs: Creates a LIFO worker queue.

attributes.value: / Tasks are pushed and popped from the same end.

defs.name: stealer
defs.docs: Creates a stealer for this queue.

attributes.value: / Creates a stealer for this queue.
/ The returned stealer can be shared among threads and cloned.

defs.name: is_empty
defs.docs: Returns `true` if the queue is empty.

attributes.value: / Returns `true` if the queue is empty.

defs.docs: Returns the number of tasks in the deque.

attributes.value: / Returns the number of tasks in the deque.

defs.name: push
defs.docs: Pushes a task into the queue.

attributes.value: / Pushes a task into the queue.

defs.name: pop
defs.docs: Pops a task from the queue.

attributes.value: / Pops a task from the queue.

defs.name: Stealer
defs.docs: A stealer handle of a worker queue.

attributes.value: / A stealer handle of a worker queue.
/ Stealers can be shared among threads.
/ Task schedulers typically have a single worker queue per worker thread.

defs.name: steal
defs.docs: Steals a task from the queue.

attributes.value: / Steals a task from the queue.

defs.name: steal_batch
defs.docs: Steals a batch of tasks and pushes them into another worker.

attributes.value: / Steals a batch of tasks and pushes them into another worker.
/ How many tasks exactly will be stolen is not specified. That said, this method will try to
/ steal around half of the tasks in the queue, but also not more than some constant limit.

defs.name: steal_batch_and_pop
defs.docs: Steals a batch of tasks, pushes them into another worker, and pops a task from that worker.

attributes.value: / Steals a batch of tasks, pushes them into another worker, and pops a task from that worker.
/ How many tasks exactly will be stolen is not specified. That said, this method will try to
/ steal around half of the tasks in the queue, but also not more than some constant limit.

defs.name: Injector
defs.docs: An injector queue.

attributes.value: / This is a FIFO queue that can be shared among multiple threads. Task schedulers typically have
/ a single injector queue, which is the entry point for new tasks.

defs.docs: Creates a new injector queue.

/ How many tasks exactly will be stolen is not specified. That said, this method will try to
/ steal around half of the tasks in the queue, but also not more than some constant limit.

defs.docs: Steals a batch of tasks, pushes them into a worker, and pops a task from that worker.

defs.name: Steal
defs.value: pub enum Steal<T> { Empty, Success(T), Retry, }
defs.docs: Possible outcomes of a steal operation.

attributes.value: / Possible outcomes of a steal operation.
/ There are lots of ways to chain results of steal operations together:

defs.name: is_empty
defs.docs: Returns `true` if the queue was empty at the time of stealing.

attributes.value: / Returns `true` if the queue was empty at the time of stealing.

defs.name: is_success
defs.docs: Returns `true` if at least one task was stolen.

attributes.value: / Returns `true` if at least one task was stolen.

defs.name: is_retry
defs.docs: Returns `true` if the steal operation needs to be retried.

defs.name: success
defs.docs: Returns the result of the operation, if successful.

defs.name: or_else
defs.value: pub fn or_else<F>(Self, F) -> Steal<T> where F: FnOnce() -> Steal<T>
defs.docs: If no task was stolen, attempts another steal operation.

attributes.value: / If no task was stolen, attempts another steal operation.
/ Returns this steal result if it is `Success`. Otherwise, closure `f` is invoked and then:
/ * If the second steal resulted in `Success`, it is returned.
/ * If both steals were unsuccessful but any resulted in `Retry`, then `Retry` is returned.
/ * If both resulted in `None`, then `None` is returned.
